title: Jannah (Paradise) — Thematic Facts (Qur'an, Sahih Hadith, Classical Tafsir)
generated_by: GPT (compiled from Qur'an, Sahih Hadith, Ibn Kathir, Al-Qurtubi, Al-Tabari, Ibn Hajar, Al-Nawawi)
notes: Each fact uses only Qur'an, sahih/hasan hadith, or classical tafsir. 'authenticity' indicates primary source strength. 'interpretation' flags whether scholars treat it literally or with caution.

themes.title: Physical Environment
themes.summary: Gardens, rivers, trees, palaces and the general landscape of Paradise.

facts.fact: Gardens (jannat) with rivers flowing beneath them are a primary descriptor of Paradise.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir explains 'gardens beneath which rivers flow' as a recurring Qur'anic image of Jannah's enduring bounty.

facts.fact: There are rivers of water, milk, honey, and pure wine in Paradise.
facts.scholar_note: Classical tafsir (Ibn Kathir) treats the four rivers as literal blessings, emphasizing purity and difference from worldly analogues.

facts.fact: Palaces, lofty dwellings, and tents—some described as hollowed pearls—are among the abodes.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim (hadith about dwellings); Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Hadith literature (Bukhari/Muslim) mentions tents and homes made of pearls; scholars generally accept these narrations as describing real rewards.

facts.fact: A special tree exists whose shade stretches a journey of a hundred years.
facts.scholar_note: Found in Bukhari and Muslim; scholars take its enormous size as literal

facts.fact: The width and scope of Paradise are vast — described as comparable to the heavens and the earth in reward and extent.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir emphasizes the vastness to convey scale rather than precise cosmological measurements.

facts.fact: Rivers flow beneath palaces and gardens; inhabitants often recline on raised couches overlooking flowing water.
facts.scholar_note: Many verses pair couches/sofas with rivers to depict restful luxury.

themes.title: Inhabitants & Companions
themes.summary: Who lives in Paradise, their appearance, and companions (including hur al-’ayn).

facts.fact: Believers of varying ranks will dwell there—Prophets, martyrs, the righteous—and one’s rank corresponds to deeds.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others emphasize gradation according to deeds and stations.

facts.fact: Inhabitants will be youthful, often described as around the age of thirty-three (appearance of perpetual youth).
facts.reference: Sunan al-Tirmidhi 2545; Sahih Muslim narrations on appearance
facts.scholar_note: Hadith describe youthful appearance; scholars state this indicates perpetual vigor.

facts.fact: Hur al-’ayn (pure companions) are described in the Qur’an and hadith as pure and reserved for Paradise.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains hur al-’ayn as pure companions; detail beyond the Qur’an is primarily from hadith and scholarly explanation.

facts.fact: People in Paradise will be with their righteous family members if they wished (reunion is promised for those who are righteous).
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir notes conditional reunification for those united by faith and righteousness.

facts.fact: The lowest person in Paradise will have a share vastly superior to the whole worldly life—Hadith mention multiplicative rewards.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith emphasize scale and abundance compared to worldly wealth.

facts.fact: People will be served by youthful attendants described in Qur’an imagery as 'like scattered pearls'.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir interprets 'scattered pearls' as imagery for the beauty and order of servants; cautions about over-literalizing social roles.

themes.title: Clothing, Jewelry & Furnishings
themes.summary: Garments, jewelry, thrones, and seating described for Jannah's dwellers.

facts.fact: Dwellers will wear garments of fine silk and brocade.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir notes silk and brocade symbolize enduring and elevated adornment.

facts.fact: They will wear bracelets of gold and pearls.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains these ornaments signify honor and beauty, not material ostentation.

facts.fact: Raised couches and thrones (mahali) are repeatedly mentioned as places of repose and company.
facts.scholar_note: Thrones and couches denote comfort and status; Bukhari/Muslim include hadith about reclining in rows.

facts.fact: There are vessels of gold and cups passed among inhabitants.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir explains golden vessels as symbols of perpetual provision.

facts.fact: Tents made from hollowed pearls are narrated in sahih hadith as individual abodes.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith mentions huge pearls as tents; scholars accept as descriptions of reward.

facts.fact: Decor and furnishings will be of precious materials—gold, silver, pearls—indicating permanence and honor.
facts.scholar_note: Classical tafsir views precious materials as expressions of eternal honor.

themes.title: Food & Drink
themes.summary: Fruits, meats, drinks, and the nature of sustenance in Paradise.

facts.fact: Fruits of Paradise hang within easy reach and are of unending variety and ease of access.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir stresses ease and abundance, contrasting worldly toil for fruit.

facts.fact: People will be served meat and fruits as they desire—completely satisfying and without digestive need.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith clarifies that inhabitants will eat without the worldly consequences (no excretion).

facts.fact: There is sealed, pure nectar (kafur/nectar) which does not intoxicate or cause illness.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir: this drink is unlike worldly wine—pure and restful.

facts.fact: No bodily impurity (urine, stool, mucus) will occur in Paradise, despite eating and drinking.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith explicitly contrasts worldly needs and Jannah's purity.

facts.fact: Fruits will be different from worldly fruits—pure, easy to pluck, and perpetually fresh.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars underscore qualitative difference from that which we know.

facts.fact: Food and drink will be served in abundance without effort or negative aftereffects.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith and Qur'an pair to show effortless provision.

themes.title: Social Life & Activities
themes.summary: Markets, greetings, meetings, and communal life in Paradise.

facts.fact: There is a weekly gathering/market in Paradise (some narrations say every Friday) where people meet and revisit the worldly life as memories.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith describes a market-like meeting used for joy and exchange of blessings.

facts.fact: People will greet each other with peace (salam) and will be free of envy or hatred.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir highlights the social perfection—unbroken bonds and pure relations.

facts.fact: Residents will remember the worldly life only as a brief thing (memories without pain), often as a moment or a glimpse.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars explain this to show eternal perspective.

facts.fact: People will be seated in rows facing each other and will enjoy conversation, laughter, and scenes of joy.
facts.scholar_note: Classical tafsir links such verses to communal delight.

facts.fact: There will be no idle speech, backbiting, or harmful talk—only words of peace and praise.
facts.scholar_note: Indicates moral purity of speech.

facts.fact: Angels enter through every gate to greet the inhabitants with peace and blessings.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir describes angelic felicitation as a sign of honor.

themes.title: Spiritual Joys & Seeing Allah
themes.summary: The spiritual and transcendent rewards, foremost being the vision of the Lord.

facts.fact: The greatest bliss of Paradise is the beatific vision — seeing Allah — affirmed in sahih hadith.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari 7444; Sahih Muslim 181; Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Classical consensus sees the vision of Allah as the highest reward; tafsir literature discusses theological implications.

facts.fact: Residents will experience perfection of heart: no hatred, envy, anxiety, or grief.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains spiritual purity as part of eternal felicity.

facts.fact: The spiritual contentment in Paradise is permanent; joy will not fade and will increase.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars emphasize 'everlasting' aspects of divine pleasure.

facts.fact: Glorification and remembrance of Allah will be effortless and natural—part of Paradise's delight.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith mentions dhikr as natural repose.

facts.fact: There will be no trials, sorrow, pain, or fatigue—pure, uninterrupted ecstasy.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir contrasts Paradise's permanence with temporal worldly trials.

facts.fact: Blessings will increase according to deeds and divine generosity—spiritual ranks vary.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others clarify that rewards are both just and abundant.

themes.title: Ranks, Entry & Gates
themes.summary: Gates, highest levels (Al-Firdaws), admission criteria and ranks inside Paradise.

facts.fact: Paradise has eight gates, each gate associated with particular acts of worship or groups mentioned in hadith.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith narrations link gates to categories (e.g., prayer, charity), tafsir expands on symbolism.

facts.fact: Al-Firdaws (al-firdaus) is described as the highest and central part of Paradise beneath the Throne of Allah.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars stress the excellence and centrality of al-Firdaws.

facts.fact: Admission is by Allah's mercy and by faith and righteous action; intercession (shafa'ah) is a promised mercy for some.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir and hadith discuss limits and the role of mercy and intercession.

facts.fact: Ranks differ: people are placed according to deeds—Prophets, martyrs, sincere worshippers occupy higher stations.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and Al-Qurtubi detail rank distinctions.

facts.fact: The first to enter Paradise will include the prophets and the most righteous; the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is described as among the first.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith corpus marks key figures entering early as honorific precedence.

facts.fact: Some believers who sinned may enter Hell temporarily for purification and later be admitted to Paradise by Allah’s mercy (as per sahih narrations).
facts.scholar_note: Scholars explain this as part of divine justice and mercy—Muslims who die with major sin without repentance may be purified.

themes.title: Measurements & Extraordinary Dimensions
themes.summary: Narrated sizes, distances, and physical exaggerations used to convey majesty and scale.

facts.fact: Some hadith describe enormous physical attributes (e.g., tents/homes measured in wide spans, huge teeth, large distances) to denote scale.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim; Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Scholars accept narrated magnitudes but caution that some may be metaphorical for scale rather than literal engineering specs.

facts.fact: There are hadith specifying enormous sizes for some Paradise features (e.g., a tent of a believer as a hollowed pearl many miles wide).
facts.scholar_note: Hadith are taken as authentic; tafsir authors discuss whether to accept these literally or as indicative of immense reward.

facts.fact: Trees and shades are sometimes given journeys or time-measures (e.g., shade spanning a hundred years) to communicate immensity.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars generally accept the hadith; debate focuses on whether 'hundred years' is literal distance/time or hyperbolic to convey vastness.

facts.fact: The rewards of the lowest person in Paradise are said to surpass the entire world many times over (Hadiths express this multiplicative idea).
facts.scholar_note: This shows qualitative, not only quantitative, superiority.

facts.fact: Descriptions sometimes use travel-time metaphors to express size (e.g., 'a tree whose shade a traveler would cross in many years').
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir notes rhetorical use to convey grandeur.

facts.fact: Tafsir literature often reframes extraordinary measurements as signs of unimaginable reward rather than physical blueprints.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars stress that human concepts of measure are inadequate to capture eternal realities.

themes.title: Emotional State & Purity
themes.summary: No sorrow, no fatigue, absence of impurity and perfect contentment.

facts.fact: There will be no grief, fear, anxiety, or sadness in Paradise.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir: complete emotional perfection and peace are central attributes.

facts.fact: Inhabitants will not suffer any disease, aging, or death—perpetual health and youthfulness are promised.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith includes explicit statements about absence of sickness, aging, and death.

facts.fact: There will be no bodily impurities (no urine, stool, mucus), yet pleasures of eating/drinking will remain.
facts.scholar_note: A strong hadith stressing the qualitative difference of bodily functioning in Paradise.

facts.fact: Scent in Paradise is pure; inhabitants sweat a fragrance like musk instead of foul perspiration.
facts.scholar_note: Described in hadith as musk-scented sweat—indicates refined bodily state.

facts.fact: Hearts will be united—no envy, hatred or broken ties; people will be content and loving.
facts.scholar_note: Hadith and Qur'an together depict moral perfection among inhabitants.

facts.fact: Joy and laughter are described as part of social felicity—memories of hardship become trivial.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars emphasize remedial aspect—worldly pains become insignificant.

themes.title: Warnings, Causes & Access
themes.summary: What leads to Jannah, warnings, mercy, and the relation of deeds/mercy to entry.

facts.fact: Entry to Paradise is by Allah’s mercy; righteous deeds and faith are the means, but ultimately acceptance is by divine mercy.
facts.reference: Qur'an 4:123; Sahih Hadith on mercy and deeds
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir literature repeatedly stresses the balance of divine justice and mercy.

facts.fact: Belief (iman) and righteous action (amal salih) are repeatedly given as the cause for Paradise.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir: practical examples include prayer, fasting, charity.

facts.fact: Warnings and admonitions in Qur’an and hadith show that sinful behavior, ingratitude, and hypocrisy imperil admission.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others compile lists of culpable acts; scholars emphasize repentance.

facts.fact: Intercession (shafa'ah) is a promised mercy; the Prophet ﷺ and others will intercede by Allah’s permission.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim (hadith on shafa'ah)
facts.scholar_note: Major theological works discuss limits and conditions of intercession.

facts.fact: Consistent small righteous deeds are emphasized (hadith about small acts accumulating rewards leading to Paradise).
facts.scholar_note: Hadiths encourage steady practice; scholars emphasize sustainability of worship.

facts.fact: Paradise is described as surrounded by hardships—the path to it entails struggle, trials, and moral vigilance.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari 6487; Qur'an passages on trials
facts.scholar_note: Hadith metaphorically and literally describes hardships that refine believers.
